report_title: IBISWorld | Cotton Farming in the US Jun 2024
executive_summary: The Cotton Farming industry has experienced extremely volatile operating conditions over the past five years. Surging commodity prices immediately following the pandemic contributed to a partial resurgence but made substitutes more attractive. Trade wars and an appreciating dollar caused exports to fall. Since exports constitute a significant source of revenue for cotton farmers, their poor performance negatively impacted operators. As interest rates have risen recently, cotton farmers have held off on purchasing better machines, hindering crop yields. Overall, revenue for cotton farmers is forecast to creep up at a CAGR of only 0.2% to $8.3 billion over the five years to 2024. However, the Federal Reserve is expected to lower interest rates by the end of 2024, driving downstream demand and allowing cotton farmers to invest in new equipment. In 2024, revenue is expected to grow an estimated 18.1%. Cotton farmers will face a resurgence over the next five years, as steadily rising incomes will boost downstream demand, aiding revenue. Commodity prices will be less volatile, so farmers won't face as many revenue drops resulting from the plunging price of cotton. Since the US dollar will depreciate, exports will recover, benefiting operators. Innovations, such as biotechnology, precision agriculture and new pesticides, will increase crop yields, raising sales for farmers. Overall, revenue for cotton farmers is forecast to rise at a CAGR of 5.4% to $10.7 billion over the five years to 2029, when profit is expected to account for 21.0% of revenue, a strong increase from five years prior.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling cotton prices caused revenue to falter
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cotton farms benefit from increases in the world price of cotton because demand for cotton is inelastic enough that farms generate higher revenue when prices rise. Immediately following the pandemic, prices soared as supply chain disruptions created a shortage of cotton. When prices rose, so did revenue. Cotton prices have begun to decline, returning to a more stable place but driving revenue back down from their inflated position.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Weak export markets have diminished opportunities for cotton farmers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Exports have fallen during the current period, as the appreciating US dollar has made domestically produced goods more expensive. Since exports comprise most of the industry's revenue, their poor performance has caused revenue to contract. As trade relations with China improved, China removed its tariffs on cotton, allowing the value of exports to return to growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising interest rates create new problems for operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As inflation reached record highs in the United States in 2022, the Federal Reserve has pushed interest rates up to reduce prices. When borrowing costs are higher, farmers are less likely to purchase new and better equipment, constraining output. Many downstream cotton buyers won't engage in new investments, reducing downstream demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Steady income growth will benefit downstream markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The economy is expected to withstand current problems related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, as economic growth is forecast to be strong during the outlook period. Steadily rising incomes and consumer spending will boost spending on discretionary materials, such as clothing and textiles, so the industry's downstream buyers will face a surge in revenue. Since cotton farmers' buyers will face higher demand, they will purchase more cotton, boosting revenue for operators.

The US dollar is expected to depreciate, making domestically produced goods seem less expensive to foreigners and raising exports. Since export markets are so intertwined with US cotton farmers, surging exports will provide a significant revenue stream for operators.

Farmers have started to use technology, such as precision agriculture, to monitor crops more effectively. Biotechnology will make cottonseed more efficient, while new pesticides will keep crops from being destroyed. These innovations will increase crop yields, boosting revenue for cotton farmers.

products_and_services.product_description: Cotton is a major agricultural crop grown in the United States.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Operate in a location with appropriate water supply, soil type and climate
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Optimal water supply, fertile soil and favorable climate conditions are crucial for cotton farming. Geographically advantageous locations can maximize yield and quality, giving farmers a competitive edge.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Operate in a location that is close to key markets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Proximity to key markets reduces transportation costs and ensures faster delivery times. This geographic advantage helps cotton farmers meet market demands efficiently and respond quickly to customer needs, thus enhancing competitiveness.

business_locations.location_description: Texas has the highest concentration of cotton farmers since it has lots of arable land and a humid climate.
The Plains region is very large geographically but has a low population.
Missouri has 32.1% of cotton farming establishments.
Florida has 14.8% of cotton farming establishments.
North Carolina has 11.5% of cotton farming establishments.
California has 11.3% of cotton farming establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Cotton farming is subject to environmental regulations related to pesticide and fertilizer use.

barriers_points.barrier_description: While the licensing required to become a cotton farmer is light, potential entrants must contend with the environmental, labor and other forms of regulation imposed on them.

Entrants must purchase physical capital (e.g., tractors, machines, drones), seeds, chemicals and fertilizer to grow cotton. They must also secure wages for their workers and be in a place with ample water.
While cotton farmers sell similar products, branding is nearly nonexistent since operators don't sell directly to consumers. Farmers differentiate themselves by offering competitive prices.

factors_decreased_barrier: Invest in new equipment to enhance mechanical efficiency and improve productivity

basis_points.basis_description: Maximizing resource use and streamlining operations can help cotton farmers reduce costs and increase productivity.
Implementing automation can significantly enhance productivity and lower labor costs.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Reliance on trade, input prices and economic conditions make the industry volatile, encouraging many small farms to merge with larger ones.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low barriers to entry encourage fragmentation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Barriers to entry for cotton farming are lower than in other agricultural industries because cotton farming faces fewer regulations than similar crops.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases, including chemicals, fertilizers, seeds, fuel and electricity, are expected to comprise 35.5% of revenue in 2023.
Wages are anticipated to make up only 3.5% of revenue in 2023 as automation reduces labor requirements.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: High property, plant and equipment costs
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry has high property, plant and equipment costs.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue is highly volatile due to fluctuations in commodity prices for cotton.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: There is increasing use of technologies like drones and other machinery.

FAQs.question: What are the key financial benchmarks for the cotton farming industry?
FAQs.answer: Some key financial benchmarks are: Profit margin of 17.9%, average wage of $36,496, largest cost is purchases at 39.7% of revenue.

FAQs.question: What trends are impacting industry costs?
FAQs.answer: Purchases are projected at 35.5% of revenue in 2023. Wages have decreased due to increased automation.

FAQs.question: What are some key financial ratios for the industry?
FAQs.answer: Some key ratios include: EBIT/Revenue 29.7%, EBITDA/Revenue 36.3%, leverage ratio 2.8.

FAQs.question: What are the projected revenue and employment figures for the next few years?
FAQs.answer: Projected revenue is $8.3 billion in 2024, $9.0 billion in 2025, and $10.0 billion in 2026. Projected employment is 10,741 in 2024.
